questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is seen in patients with brain stem injury?
questions.explanation:
Patients with brain stem injury develop type 2 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 
and high pCO2. Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the 
blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia. 662

questions.question:
Question 2: A 45-year-old man underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The 
surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Two days later, he developed features of 
respiratory failure. Which of the following types is likely to be present in him?
questions.explanation:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to 
lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him. Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure. After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in 
muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units. Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright 
positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure 
ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient is admitted for myocardial infarction complicated by severe mitral regurgitation. He 
suddenly develops shortness of breath, decreased urine output, and drowsiness. Blood 
pressure is 86/40 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and respiratory rate 24 per minute. Which of the 
following statements is false?

options.a: Up to 40% of cardiac output may be distributed to the respiratory muscles
options.b: Patient will develop type 2 respiratory failure
options.c: Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment of choice
options.d: Batwing appearance can be expected on an x-ray

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. He is likely to develop type 4 
respiratory failure, not type 2. Patients in cardiogenic shock often have respiratory distress secondary to acute pulmonary edema 
(batwing appearance on x-ray). This increases the requirement of oxygen delivery to the 
respiratory muscles from <5% to up to 40% of cardiac output. Hypoperfusion and increased oxygen requirement lead to inadequate perfusion of respiratory 
muscles which causes type 4 respiratory failure. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the treatment of choice.

The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of ARDS (acute 
respiratory distress syndrome) secondary to acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis gives rise to 
inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. CXR features in ARDS: • Early findings - normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), bilateral and which obscure 
the pulmonary vascular markings • Late findings - these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse Clinical disorders commonly associated with ARDS: • Direct lung injury: • Pneumonia • Aspiration of gastric contents • Pulmonary contusion 663

questions.question: Question 5: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except
questions.explanation:
Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg. PaO2/FiO2: 200 - 300 mm/Hg 
is classified as mild ARDS. Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition:(requires each of the following criteria to be 
present to diagnose ARDS) • Onset - Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun < 1 week of a known clinical insult • Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: on a chest X-ray image or CT scan • Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective 
assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause. • Impairment of oxygenation: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS. questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is least likely to be present in patients with ARDS?
questions.explanation:
Increased left atrial pressure is not likely to be present in ARDS. ARDS is characterized by • PCWP of 18 mmHg with normal LA pressure • Decreased pulmonary compliance • Increased pulmonary artery pressure • Severe hypoxemia 665

questions.question:
Question 7: A fisherman was rushed to the ED following a near-drowning incident. On arrival, he was 
unconscious and was not breathing. He was resuscitated and stabilized. A few hours later, he 
developed sudden onset breathlessness and low saturation. Chest X-ray showed diffuse 
alveolar opacities. He was started on mechanical ventilation. What will be the recommended 
ventilator setting for him?

options.a: Platelets have a role in the development of HOA

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning. The ventilator setting 
recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP. Drowning causes direct lung injury. The aspiration of water into the lungs damages the surfactant. 
This disrupts the alveolar-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema, resulting in ARDS. The ventilator settings recommended in ARDS are: • Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli. • High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of 
the expiration and improves oxygenation. 666
